questions.question_title: Which of the following operations are INCORRECT?

options.description:
float a = 3.14; a = a%3; gives "Illegal use of floating point" error. 
The modulus (%) operator can only be used on integer types. We have to use fmod() function in math.h for float values.

questions.question_title: Which of the declaration is correct?

options.description:
int length; denotes that variable length is int(integer) data type.


char int; here int is a keyword cannot be used a variable name.

int long; here long is a keyword cannot be used a variable name.
float double; here double is a keyword cannot be used a variable name.
So, the answer is int length;(Option A).

questions.question_title: Which of the following correctly represents a long double constant?

options.description:
6.68 is double. 
6.68L is long double constant. 
6.68f is float constant. 
6.68LF is not allowed in c.
In 2 and 3 semicolon are missing in structure element.

typedef long a;extern int a c; while compiling this statement becomes extern int long c;. This will result in to "Declaration syntax error".


typedef long a;extern a int c; while compiling this statement becomes extern long int c;. This will result in to "Too many types in declaration error".


typedef long a;extern a c; while compiling this statement becomes extern long c;. This is a valid c declaration statement. It says variable c is long data type and defined in some other file or module.

So, Option C is the correct answer.
Option B gives "Undefined structure in 'aa'" error.
